message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and nasal inspection suggests a nasal cavity mass. A CT scan of the head with contrast is the most appropriate next diagnostic step to evaluate the extent and characteristics of the mass before considering a biopsy or surgical intervention. Coagulation tests and sweat chloride tests are not relevant to this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest a nasal mass, which may be a nasal polyp or a more serious condition like a tumor. A CT scan of the head with contrast is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis to evaluate the extent and nature of the mass. Coagulation tests and sweat chloride test are not relevant in this case, and a punch biopsy may be considered after imaging studies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a nasal cavity mass. A CT scan of the head with contrast is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis to visualize the mass and its location. Coagulation tests would not be necessary in this case. A sweat chloride test is used to diagnose cystic fibrosis, which is not related to the symptoms. A punch biopsy may be considered, but only after imaging studies have been completed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and nasal inspection suggest that the most likely diagnosis is a nasal tumor. A CT scan with contrast is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis as it can help evaluate the size and extent of the tumor. Coagulation tests and sweat chloride tests are not relevant to this case. A punch biopsy may be necessary later on, but it is not the initial step in diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a nasal mass that bleeds on touch, which is highly suggestive of a juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). CT scan with contrast is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis, as it can provide information about the extent and location of the mass. Coagulation tests and punch biopsy are not as useful in diagnosing JNA, and a sweat chloride test is not relevant to this clinical scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the physical exam suggest that the most likely diagnosis is a nasal polyp. A CT scan of the head with contrast is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis and to evaluate the extent of the lesion. Coagulation tests and sweat chloride tests are not relevant to this diagnosis. A punch biopsy may be needed for histologic evaluation, but it should not be the first test done to establish the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a nasal mass, which makes a CT scan of the head with contrast the most appropriate next step in diagnosis. Coagulation tests and sweat chloride tests are not related to this condition, and a punch biopsy may be considered after additional diagnostic testing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest a nasal mass, and a CT scan is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis to determine the location, extent and character of the mass. Coagulation tests are unrelated to the patient’s symptoms, and sweat chloride test is used to diagnose cystic fibrosis, which is not suggested by the patient’s medical history or symptoms. Punch biopsy may be necessary for definitive diagnosis but is not the initial step in diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest a mass in the nasal cavity, which may be a tumor or polyp. CT scan with contrast would provide visualization of the mass and surrounding structures, helping to diagnose the problem. Coagulation tests and sweat chloride test are not relevant to this case, and punch biopsy is invasive and not necessarily needed at this stage.

We refer to the Mayo Clinic article on nasal and sinus tumors for help. The boy's symptoms and examination findings suggest a nasal mass, and a CT scan of the head with contrast is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis. Coagulation tests and sweat chloride test are not indicated for this presentation, and a punch biopsy of the mass may be necessary but should not be the initial step in diagnosis.
